Title: Crime and Punishment
Summary: "Crime and Punishment" is a psychological novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky. It follows the story of Rodion Raskolnikov, a former law student in St. Petersburg, who formulates a plan to kill an unscrupulous pawnbroker to liberate himself from poverty. After committing the murder, Raskolnikov is consumed by guilt and paranoia. He engages in a cat-and-mouse game with the investigator Porfiry Petrovich and wrestles with the moral implications of his crime. His mental torment is alleviated when he confesses and is sentenced to Siberia. There, with the help of the prostitute Sonya, who follows him out of love, he begins his journey towards redemption and moral regeneration.

Title: The Brothers Karamazov

Title: Notes from Underground
Summary: "Notes from Underground" by Fyodor Dostoevsky is a profound psychological exploration of the human condition. The unnamed narrator, a bitter and misanthropic man living in St. Petersburg, rejects societal norms and retreats into self-imposed isolation, or the 'underground'. The book is divided into two parts: the first, a philosophical monologue on free will, determinism, and rational egoism; the second, a series of anecdotes from the narrator's life illustrating his theories. The narrator's self-loathing, spite, and existential crisis reflect Dostoevsky's critique of Enlightenment rationalism and Romantic idealism. The book is a stark portrayal of human alienation and despair.
